column1: Przemyśl owes its long and rich history to the advantages of its geographic location. The city lies in an area connecting mountains and lowlands known as the Przemyśl Gate (Brama Przemyska)
column3: and fertile soil. It also lies on the navigable San River. Important trade routes that connect Central Europe from Przemyśl ensure the city's importance.

column1: Different names in various languages have identified the city throughout its history. Selected languages include: Bulgarian: Пшемишъл (Pshemishǎl); Czech: Přemyšl; German: Premissel
column3: Premslen; Latin: Premislia; Ukrainian: Перемишль (Peremyshlj); and Yiddish: פּשעמישל‎ (Pshemishl).

column1: Przemyśl is the second-oldest city (after Kraków) in southern Poland
column2: dating back to at least the 8th century
column3: when it was the site of a fortified grod belonging to the Lendians (Lendizi)
column4: a West Slavic tribe.  In the 9th century
column5: the fortified settlement and the surrounding region became part of Great Moravia. Most likely
column6: the city's name dates back to the Moravian period. Also
column7: archeological remains testify to the presence of a Christian monastic settlement as early as the 9th century.Upon the invasion of the Hungarian tribes into the heart of the Great Moravian Empire around 899
column8: the local Lendians declared allegiance to the Hungarians. The region then became a site of contention between Poland
column9: Rus and Hungary beginning in at least the 9th century
column10: with Przemyśl along with other Cherven Grods
column11: falling under the control of the Polans (Polanie)
column12: who would in the 10th century under the rule of Mieszko I establish the Polish state. The city was mentioned by Nestor the Chronicler

column15: and in 1031 it was retaken by Rus. Around the year 1069
column17: after Bolesław II the Generous retook the town and temporarily made it his residence. In 1085
column18: the town became the capital of a semi-independence Principality of Peremyshl under the lordship of Rus.

column1: The palatium complex including a Latin rotunda was built during the rule of the Polish king Bolesław I the Brave in the 11th century. Sometime before 1218

column1: Przemyśl later became part of the Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia.
=== Kingdom of Poland and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth ===

column6: the city's population consisted of a great number of nationalities
column11: Armenians and Ruthenians. The long period of prosperity enabled the construction of public buildings such as the Renaissance town hall and the Old Synagogue of 1559. Also
column12: a Jesuit college was founded in the city in 1617.

column1: The prosperity came to an end in the middle of the 17th century

column1: With technological progress in artillery during the second half of the 19th century
column2: the old fortifications rapidly became obsolete. The longer range of rifled artillery necessitated the redesign of fortresses so that they would be larger and able to resist the newly available guns. To achieve this
column3: between the years 1888 and 1914 Przemyśl was turned into a first-class fortress
column4: the third-largest in Europe out of about 200 that were built in this period. Around the city
column5: in a circle of circumference 45 km (28 mi)
column6: 44 forts of various sizes were built. The older fortifications were modernised to provide the fortress with an internal defence ring. The fortress was designed to accommodate 85
column7: 000 soldiers and 956 cannons of all sorts
column10: at the start of the First World War
column11: Russian forces defeated Austro-Hungarian forces in the opening engagements and advanced rapidly into Galicia. The Przemyśl fortress fulfilled its mission very effectively
column13: 000 strong Russian army advancing upon the Carpathian Passes and Kraków
column14: the Lesser Poland regional capital. The first siege was lifted by a temporary Austro-Hungarian advance. However
column15: the Russian army resumed its advance and initiated a second siege of the fortress of Przemyśl in October 1914. This time relief attempts were unsuccessful. Due to lack of food and exhaustion of its defenders
column16: the fortress surrendered on 22 March 1915. The Russians captured 126
column17: 000 prisoners and 700 big guns. Before the surrender
column18: the complete destruction of all fortifications was carried out. The Russians did not linger in Przemyśl. A renewed offensive by the Central Powers recaptured the destroyed fortress on 3 June 1915. During the fighting around Przemyśl

column1: At the end of World War I
column2: Przemyśl became disputed between renascent Poland and the West Ukrainian People's Republic. On 1 November 1918
column3: a local provisional government was formed with representatives of Polish
column5: and Ruthenian inhabitants of the area. However
column7: a Ukrainian military unit overthrew the government
column8: arrested its leader and captured the eastern part of the city. The Ukrainian army was checked by a small Polish self-defence unit formed of World War I veterans. Also
column9: numerous young Polish volunteers from Przemyśl's high schools
column10: later to be known as Przemyśl Orlęta
column11: The Eaglets of Przemyśl (in a similar manner to more famous Lwów Eaglets)
column12: joined the host. The battlefront divided the city along the river San
column13: with the western borough of Zasanie held in Polish hands and the Old Town controlled by the Ukrainians. Neither Poles nor Ukrainians could effectively cross the San river
column14: so both opposing parties decided to wait for a relief force from the outside. That race was won by the Polish reinforcements and the volunteer expeditionary unit formed in Kraków arrived in Przemyśl on 10 November 1918. When the subsequent Polish ultimatum to the Ukrainians remained unanswered
column15: on 11–12 November the Polish forces crossed the San and forced out the outnumbered Ukrainians from the city in what became known as the 1918 Battle of Przemyśl.

column1: After the end of the Polish–Ukrainian War and the Polish–Bolshevik War that followed
column2: the city became a part of the Second Polish Republic. Although the capital of the voivodship was in Lwów (see: Lwów Voivodeship)
column3: Przemyśl recovered its nodal position as a seat of local church administration
column4: as well as the garrison of the 10th Military District of the Polish Army — a staff unit charged with organizing the defence of roughly 10% of the territory of pre-war Poland. As of 1931
column6: 272 and was the biggest city in southern Poland between Kraków and Lwów.

column2: the German and Polish armies fought the Battle of Przemyśl in and around the city. The four-day battle was followed by three days of massacres carried out by the German soldiers and police against hundreds of Jews who lived in the city. In total
column3: over 500 Jews were murdered in and around the city and the vast majority of the city's Jewish population was deported across the San River into the portion of Poland that was occupied by the Soviet Union. The border between the two invaders ran through the middle of the city along the San River until June 1941. During the Soviet occupation Przemyśl was incorporated to the Ukrainian SSR in the atmosphere of NKVD terror as thousands of Jews were ordered to be deported. It became part of the newly established Drohobych Oblast. In 1940
column4: the city became an administrative center of Peremyshl Uyezd with the Peremyshl Fortified District established along the Nazi-Soviet frontier before the German attack against the USSR in 1941.

column1: The town's population increased due to a large influx of Jewish refugees from the General Government who sought to cross the border to Romania. It is estimated that by mid-1941 the Jewish population of the city had grown to roughly 16

column8: including the Tempel Synagogue and the Old Synagogue were destroyed; the New Synagogue
column10: and all commercial and residential real estate belonging to Jews were expropriated.The ghetto in Przemyśl was sealed off from the outside on 14 July 1942. By that time

Until September 1943 almost all Jews were sent to the Auschwitz or Belzec extermination camps. The local branches of the Polish underground and the Żegota managed to save 415 Jews. According to a postwar investigation in German archives

column27: and Podgórski families.The Red Army retook the town from German forces on 27 July 1944. On 16 August 1945
